awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Paleoclimatic and Palenvironmental Characterization of Early Pleistocene Sites
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will investigate the impact of climate and environmental change on the migration of early human ancestors out of Africa and their adaptation to novel environments 1.8 million years ago. Previous scholarship on climate-human relationship focused on unique morphological and behavioral adaptations of early humans to hot, arid and open savanna habitats, and causally linked the dispersal of early humans with the development of savanna grasslands in Eurasia. However, evidence for an expansion of a savanna corridor at broad millennial temporal scales and/or at a global continental spatial scale is ambiguous and necessitates consideration that disparate climatic processes operating on narrower temporal scales and local spatial scales may have played a critical role in this cardinal and foundational event. Novel, state-of-the-art, complementary and interdisciplinary methods derived from archaeology and geosciences are well-placed to break new ground by focusing on seasonality and other high-resolution spatial and temporal climatic and environmental patterns as some of the driving forces for dispersal of early Homo. This collaboration of archaeologists, geochemists, paleontologists, and geologists from the United States, Israel, Republic of Georgia, and Australia will explore the unfamiliar pattern of seasonality, climate and environment which early humans faced in the Levant. Knowledge of the type, extent and degree of past biological human adaptation holds promise for illuminating issues on the distributions and capacities of modern humans in varying climatic regimes. Anthropogenic climate change is one of the most perilous processes facing humanity in the 21st century and understanding human biological limits is paramount in addressing these global concerns. The research will provide a platform for fostering professional and public discourse on the interactions throughout time among climate, environment, and human responses, enhancing science education across multiple academic levels, and supporting the recruitment of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups through mentoring aimed to create leaders in scholarship, research and public life. 

The research team will derive new data on the local climate and environment of two archaeological sites in Israel and the Republic of Georgia dating from 2 - 1.2 million years ago, which are the some of the earliest sites of humans out of Africa. Combining new dating methods, archaeological excavations, fossil analyses across the spectra of morphology, histology and chemistry will permit rigorous evaluation of the links between climate, environment and hominin population dynamics. Furthermore, the team will generate new comparative methods for the study of paleoclimatology and paleoecology, which will be used for developing a comprehensive database that will be made publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our genus, Homo, evolved in Africa ca. 2.5 million years ago (mya). Around 2 mya, we find early members of this genus across Eurasia. However, our understanding of the forces that caused this dispersal is unclear. Why was there a dispersion in this group of fossil humans and not others? How many dispersals were there? What forces caused these populations to leave, and what forces allowed them to survive in new environments? These are more than theoretical questions. They directly imply how we understand our survival ability considering the rapidly changing climate. 

It has been proposed that early Homo was adapted to savanna environments. In contrast, others suggested adapting to novel environments allowed early Homo to flourish in Eurasia's temperate climates. We argued that it was more than just the issue of open, hot, and arid vs. wooded, cool, and humid but a question of rainfall distribution during the year and the degree of seasonality. Today, the Levant has a unimodal rain distribution, which falls primarily in the winter. Did summer rains in the southern Levant facilitate the dispersal of early Homo into Eurasia? Or did they disperse into regions with a similar seasonality pattern?

To start unpacking these questions, we applied several histological methods to rodent and Hippopotamus teeth from the extensive archaeological site of 'Ubeidiya, Israel, dated to 1.6 - 1.2 mya, one of the earliest sites to record evidence of early hominins dispersing from East Africa into Eurasia. As teeth grow, they form daily layers that appear as lines in the hard outer enamel and in the softer dentine below it. These lines are visible with a microscope, once a tooth has been cut in half and then polished very thin. Occasionally, an animal experiences a stressful life event that disrupts the orderly layered enamel and dentine deposition, and this results in an accentuated band of tissue. This can be intermittent, such as from periods of illness, or related to cyclical events such as annual hibernation or seasonal resource scarcity.

Fossils of rodent teeth from ‘Ubeidiya provide a record of how frequently the region experienced especially harsh conditions during the stressful season, based on how accentuated the hibernation lines appear in their teeth. Larger animals from ‘Ubeidiya, such as hippopotamus, had longer lifespans than rodents and did not hibernate. Their teeth preserve records of seasonal stresses over months to years. In this way, different species contribute unique records of stressful events at different resolutions in time, and those records can be layered to examine patterns in seasonality. This provides unique insights into the environmental conditions experienced by early Homo in ‘Ubeidiya and points to an early origin of the genus Homo's excellent capacity for adaptability to a range of habitats. 

In analogy to our current climate crisis, our methodology of utilizing teeth from different animals to investigate climate variations at different resolutions (weekly, monthly, seasonally, yearly) could assist conservation efforts in understanding the effects of climate-driven stresses. Because teeth of different animals grow at different rates, and some animals are more sensitive to environmental change than others, analyzing the pronounced lines in teeth from animals living within the same ecosystem will reflect the magnitude to which different species are affected by the same climate-driven pressures. Moreover, the timing of stress line formation could be compared to local climate history records to investigate any potential relationships. Such investigations would provide additional data to help us understand the environmental impact of modern-day rapid climate change on animal populations over one or more generations.

This study contributes to the ongoing debate in paleoanthropology about the links between climate, environmental change, and hominin population dynamics. Through our academic and public presentations, we have been fostering professional and public discourse on the interactions throughout time among climate, ecology, and human evolution and demonstrate the importance of deepening our understanding of human evolution within the context of past and present environmental change.
